{{Infobox person | name = Albert Thys | image = Albert Thys (1849-1915), view 2, sculptor unknown - Royal Museum for Central Africa - DSC06710.JPG | image_size = 200px | alt = Sculpture of a young man wearing a military uniform with a prominent moustache | caption = Sculpture bust of Thys at the [[Royal Museum for Central Africa]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1849|11|28}} | birth_place = [[Dalhem]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1915|02|10|1849|11|28}} | death_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | nationality = Belgian | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Albert Thys''' (28 November 1849 – 10 February 1915) was a Belgian businessman who was active in the [[Congo Free State]]. He gave his name of Thysville to the station of Sona Qongo, currently [[Mbanza-Ngungu]] in [[Bas-Congo]].
Born in [[Dalhem]], Thys graduated at the École de guerre, before entering into the service of king [[Leopold II of Belgium]] in 1876, as secretary of the colonial businesses. After the return of [[Henry Morton Stanley]], the king sent Thys to [[England]] to propose a new expedition to Central Africa on behalf of the [[Association Internationale Africaine]]. Thys was actively involved in the organisation of the first expeditions which would lead to the constitution of the Congo Free State.
After arriving in Congo in 1887 he promoted the [[Matadi-Kinshasa Railway|Matadi-Léopoldville Railway]], which was built from 1890 to 1898. He imposed a route by the south, deviating from the [[Congo river]]. He was one of the principal craftsmen of the development and the economic development of the Congo Free State and [[Belgian Congo]]. Notably he created the {{illm|Compagnie du Congo pour le Commerce et l'Industrie|nl}} (27 December 1886) and many of its subsidiary companies: the [[Compagnie du Chemin de Fer du Congo]] (CCFC), the ''Compagnie des Magasins généraux'', the ''Société anonyme Belge pour le Commerce du Haut-Congo'', the ''Compagnie des¨Produits'', the ''[[Compagnie du Katanga]]''.
He died in [[Brussels]], aged 66, in 1915.
== Literature== {{commonscat|Albert Thys}} * {{fr icon}} Georges Defauwes, Albert Thys, de Dalhem au Congo, Collection Comté de Dalhem [http://www.dalhem.be/WEBSITE/_Download/PDFDivers/AlbertThys_Defauwes.pdf online]
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thys, Albert}} [[Category:1849 births]] [[Category:1915 deaths]] [[Category:People from Dalhem]] [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] [[Category:Congo Free State people]] [[Category:Royal Military Academy (Belgium) alumni]]

'''Aldo Garzanti''' (1883 in [[Forlì]] - 1961 in [[San Pellegrino Terme]]) was an Italian entrepreneur and publisher.<ref name="bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/aldo-garzanti_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/|title=Garzanti, Aldo|publisher=[[Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani]] - Volume 52|year=1999|accessdate=9 December 2013|language=Italian}}</ref>
==Early life== Born in Forlì, his father was a schoolteacher and follower of Garibaldi. He was educated in his native city where G. Mazzatinti introduced him to librarianship. He then studied at the Faculty of Letters in the [[University of Bologna]], graduating in 1907.<ref name="bio"/>
Immediately after graduating, he joined a group of intellectuals associated with the journal ''La Romagna nella storia, nella letteratura e nelle arti'', becoming its editor in 1911. He took a special interest in the social and economic history of the region, publishing accounts of developments from the 16th to the 18th centuries. At the same time, he took up teaching, first at the high school in [[Rimini]], then at [[Alatri]] (1909) and [[Chieri]] (1912). During the [[First World War]], he enlisted in the artillery until April 1919 when he was discharged with the rank of captain.<ref name="bio"/>
==Business career==
Immediately after the war he moved to Milan where he gave up teaching in favour of a business career, becoming the Italian agent for American chemicals producers including [[Dupont de Nemours]] and founding his own company, Dott. Aldo Garzanti Coloranti et Prodotti Chimici, a distribution outlet supplying the textile and leather industries. As a result of his success, in 1921 he was able to open his own manufacturing company, SADAF, which produced dyes and chemicals for soaking and tanning hides and leathers. In 1932, he widened his interests, opening MIRET specializing in lace and silk. The following year he created a model agricultural enterprise in [[Suvignano]], [[Tuscany]] but above all, in 1936, he acquired the Treves publishing company which was in difficulty. Created in 1861 by [[Emilio Treves]], Fratelli Treves Editori had been a leading publisher not only in [[Lombardy]] but throughout Italy. After changing its name to Casa Editrice Garzanti, he received support from [[Benito Mussolini]] which brought him lucrative commissions from the library authorities, making it one of the top publishing companies in Italy.<ref name="bio"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.garzantilibri.it/default.php?page=casaed|title=Garzanti Libri s.p.a.|publisher=Garzanti Libri|accessdate=11 December 2013 |language=Italian}}</ref>
The company suffered during the [[Second World War]] when the old Treves printing plant was bombed but Garzanti was successful in rebuilding modern facilities within a year, winning the Roncoroni prize for rapid redevelopment. In 1952, suffering from poor health, he retired as managing director of the company but remained chairman of the board.<ref name="bio"/>
==Later life== In later life, Garzanti devoted his efforts mainly to philanthropic activities, contributing to the restoration of the castle Rocca Caterina Sforza in Forlì and assisting artists through the Fondazione Livio e Maria Garzanti. In 1954, he financed the Italian expedition which successfully climbed [[K2]]. He died in 1961 at the age of 78.<ref name="bio"/>
==Family==
In 1920, Garzanti married Maria Ravasi who gave birth to their son Livio in 1921. Livio later took over the family publishing business.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/cultura/11_giugno_20/torno-novanta-anni-livio-garzanti_94474866-9b25-11e0-b9a7-5cbc176a671d.shtml|title=La crisi italiana è culturale|publisher=Corriere della Sera|accessdate=11 December 2013 |language=Italian}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Garzanti, Aldo}} [[Category:Italian publishers (people)]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:People from Forlì]]

{{Infobox company | name = Aperio Intelligence | logo = | logo_size = | type = Corporation | founded = 2014 | hq_location_city = London, United Kingdom | products = Professional Services | website = {{URL|www.aperio-intelligence.com}} }} A [[corporate intelligence]] and [[financial crime]] advisory firm based in London.<ref>{{cite web|title=Due Diligence for Businesses|url=http://www.business2community.com/strategy/10-tips-better-due-diligence-businesses-01281193#xjtrpX4zlu1VIrI7.97|publisher=[[Business 2 Community]]|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref> Aperio Intelligence specialises in conducting enhanced due diligence on high risk customers and third parties; integrity due diligence on critical acquisitions and investments; market entry and political risk analysis; and investigations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=De Buitléir|first1=Scott|title=IBM 'Making Change Work' Report Rings Truer Than Ever After 7 Years|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/scott-de-buitleir/ibm-making-change-work-re_b_8141030.html?ir=India&adsSiteOverride=in|accessdate=10 December 2015|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref>
==History== Aperio Intelligence was established in 2014 by Adrian Ford, a former director in [[KPMG LLP]]’s Forensic practice in the UK, where he specialised in corporate intelligence and international investigations. Aperio Intelligence is involved in supporting organisations in the regulated sector and those who do business in foreign markets.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 Due Diligence Tips for Business Acquisition and Buy Outs|url=http://tech.co/due-diligence-tips-business-acquisition-buy-outs-2015-06|publisher=Tech Cocktail|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=10 Must Know Tips For Selling Your Startup|url=http://news.fcrmedia.ie/latest/10-must-know-tips-for-selling-your-startup/|publisher=news.fcrmedia.ie|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref>
The Financial Crime Digest is a monthly newsletter from Aperio Intelligence, which provides a regular synopsis of activities relevant to senior decision makers seeking information on the latest trends, developments and key events.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aperio Financial Crime Digest Apr15 v1.2_BGL0739|url=http://aperio-intelligence.com/pdfs/Aperio_Financial_Crime_Digest_Apr15.pdf|publisher=www.aperio-intelligence.com|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref> The Financial Crime Digest includes information on technical developments relating to management of financial crime and current affairs.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] |name = Arthur Mutambara |image = Mutambara 2009 crop.jpg |caption = Mutambara at the 2009 World Economic Forum on Africa. |office = [[Deputy Prime Minister of Zimbabwe]] |alongside = [[Thokozani Khupe]] |term_start = 11 February 2009 |term_end = 11 September 2013 |primeminister = [[Morgan Tsvangirai]] |predecessor = Position established |successor = Position abolished |office2 = President of the [[Movement for Democratic Change – Mutambara|Movement for Democratic Change-Mutambara]] |term_start2 = 27 February 2006 |term_end2 = |predecessor2 = Position established |successor2 = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|05|25|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Rhodesia]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Movement for Democratic Change – Mutambara|Movement for Democratic Change-Mutambara]] (2005–present) |alma_mater = [[University of Zimbabwe]]
[[Merton College, Oxford]] |profession = [[Roboticist]] |religion = [[United Methodist Church]] }} '''Arthur Guseni Oliver Mutambara''' (born 25 May 1966)[http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/senate141.13789.html All you need to know about Arthur Mutambara] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416033643/http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/senate141.13789.html |date=16 April 2007 }} New Zimbabwe is a [[Zimbabwe]]an politician. He became the president of the [[Movement for Democratic Change – Ncube|Movement for Democratic Change]] (MDC) in February 2006.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4756424.stm Zimbabwe's 'outsider' faction leader] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305142059/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4756424.stm |date=5 March 2016 }} BBC News He has worked as the managing director and CEO of Africa Technology and Business Institute since September 2003. Under a [[2008 Zimbabwean political negotiations|September 2008 power-sharing agreement]], Mutambara served in the government as one of two Deputy Prime Ministers from 2009 to 2013. ==Early activism== Mutambara was president of the Student Representative Council of the University of Zimbabwe in 1988 and 1989. He led anti-government protests at the [[University of Zimbabwe]] which led to his arrest and imprisonment. He was later educated on a [[Rhodes Scholarship]] in 1991, at [[Merton College, Oxford]] in the United Kingdom where he obtained a DPhil in [[Robotics]] and Mechatronics, and in the United States where he spent time as a visiting FellowMLK Visiting Professors welcomed",{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2000/mlk-1213.html |title=MLK 1213 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104043130/http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2000/mlk-1213.html |archivedate=4 November 2013 |df=dmy }} in the same field, including both [[California Institute of Technology]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and [[FAMU - FSU College of Engineering|Florida A & M University – Florida State University College of Engineering]]. He also worked as a lecturer on Business Strategy and as a consultant for [[McKinsey & Company]]. Mutambara criticised government ministers for abusing Zimbabwe's [[land reform in Zimbabwe|land reform program]], engaging in: "monopolistic politics of domination, corruption, and petty bourgeois accumulation."Bond, Patrick. ''Uneven Zimbabwe: A Study of Finance, Development, and Underdevelopment'', 1998. Page 206. Mutambara, a self-professed admirer of [[Che Guevara]], has also expressed his intention to visit [[Cuba]] to learn more about its "successful resistance" to [[Cuban embargo|American sanctions]]. Mutambara added: "We have a lot to learn from Cuba which started [[Cuban Revolution|its revolution]] in 1959, we will continue with our solidarity, continue with the struggle and strengthen our co-operation."[http://allafrica.com/stories/200908210020.html Zimbabwe: Build on Revolution Legacy, Country Told] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011005116/http://allafrica.com/stories/200908210020.html |date=11 October 2012 }} ''All Africa'', 21 August 2009 ==Scholarly output== From March of 2002 to September of 2003, Mutambara was a professor of [[Operations Management]] at the [[University of South Africa]]'s School of Business Leadership.{{Cite web|title=Who is Who in Mutare? |publisher=Samanyika & Sons |location=Mutare, Zimbabwe |url=https://sites.google.com/site/cityofmutare/famouspeoplefrommutare?tmpl=%2Fsystem%2Fapp%2Ftemplates%2Fprint%2F&showPrintDialog=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004025845/https://sites.google.com/site/cityofmutare/famouspeoplefrommutare |archive-date=4 October 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy }} Mutambara has authored at least two books.[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Arthur-G.-O.-Mutambara/e/B001KIB98I/ref=sr_tc_2_0 Amazon UK, Books by Arthur G. O. Mutambara] His most cited paper, of his at least thriteen papers, is entitled ''Estimation and control for a modular wheeled mobile robot'' co-authored with [[Hugh F. Durrant-Whyte|Professor Hugh F. Durrant-Whyte]]. According to [[Scopus]] as of 2013 his [[h-index]] was a modest 4. ==Movement for Democratic Change== In 2005 the MDC split into two factions following a dispute over whether or not to participate in the March 2005 senatorial election. While MDC leader [[Morgan Tsvangirai]], Mutambara, and others opposed participation, [[Welshman Ncube]] and [[Gibson Sibanda]] led a faction that favoured participation. Those supporting the senate elections won narrowly against the leader Morgan Tsvangirai's vote. Tsvangirai later overruled and overturned the decision of the plebiscite citing two absent members had sent in postal votes that canceled the slender margin.{{Cite news |title=Zimbabwe Opposition: Mugabe's Price Cuts Mask Deeper Economic Problems |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2007-07-15-voa21.cfm |date=15 July 2007 |publisher=''[[VOA News]]'' |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913210005/http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2007-07/2007-07-15-voa21.cfm |archivedate=13 September 2008 |access-date=31 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }} In February 2006 at a Congress of the breakaway faction Movement for Democratic Change, Mutambara was elected as president of the party. Commenting on the election, Mutambara said, "My position was that the MDC should have boycotted those Senate elections. I guess then that makes me the anti-Senate leader of the pro-Senate MDC faction. How ridiculous can we get? That debate is now in the past, let us move on and unite our people." The choice of Mutambara as leader was said to have been inspired by the fact that he is a [[Shona people|Shona]] whereas Sibanda and Ncube are both [[Ndebele people (Zimbabwe)|Ndebele]], but realised that only a Shona candidate could win an election across the whole of Zimbabwe. Mutambara is not a member of the House of Assembly. The faction led by Tsvangirai described Mutambara's election as a nullity. In his MDC faction presidential acceptance speech,[http://amadlandawonye.wikispaces.com/MDC,+Presidential+acceptance+speech,+A+Mutambara MDC faction presidential acceptance speech] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427135734/http://amadlandawonye.wikispaces.com/MDC%2C%2BPresidential%2Bacceptance%2Bspeech%2C%2BA%2BMutambara |date=27 April 2012 }} Communist University of Johannesburg Mutambara stated, "We believe that our views on land reform in Zimbabwe are different from those of Western governments. Our approach is not driven by the interests of [[Whites in Zimbabwe|white]] farmers, but by those of all Zimbabweans, white and black. While we put the failure of the land reform program squarely on the [[ZANU–PF]] government, we also acknowledge the complicity of some Western governments which reneged on agreements, and the inertia of white farmers in seeking pre-emptive solutions." However, [[David Karimanzira]], a leading member of the ZANU–PF, alleged that Mutambara was promoted by the West after Western governments decided not to continue backing [[Morgan Tsvangirai]] because the Zimbabwean people had allegedly rejected his party manifesto. He once called the [[African Union]] a "club of dictators".[http://allafrica.com/stories/200706111569.html Zimbabwe: Era of Puppet Politics Over] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013115628/http://allafrica.com/stories/200706111569.html |date=13 October 2012 }} AllAfrica Mutambara was arrested by the Zimbabwe police on 19 May 2006 while leading a march in support of his faction's candidate on the eve of the Budiriro by-election. He was also arrested on 11 March together with other MDC leaders from the other faction. He was released without charge two days later, only to be re-arrested on 18 March at Harare Airport en route to South Africa, where his family is still based, and where he is also a leading consultant. He was also released without charge after three days in custody. ===2008 presidential election=== After Mutambara and Tsvangirai failed to unite on a single MDC candidate for the [[Zimbabwean presidential election, 2008|March 2008 presidential election]], Mutambara said on 15 February that he would not run for president and that his faction would instead back [[Simba Makoni]].Fikile Mapala, [http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/electoral155.17759.html "Mutambara withdraws from race, backs Makoni"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801030954/http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/electoral155.17759.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, newzimbabwe.com, 15 February 2008. Mutambara instead ran in the [[Zimbabwean parliamentary election, 2008|concurrent parliamentary election]] for a seat from the Zengeza East constituency, but he was placed third, with 1,322 votes, according to official results, behind the candidate of the Tsvangirai faction, who won 7,570 votes, and the ZANU–PF candidate, who won 3,042 votes.[http://www.sokwanele.com/election2008/constituency Results page for Zengeza East] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080404060118/http://www.sokwanele.com/election2008/constituency |date=4 April 2008 }} at sokwanele.com. The Tsvangirai faction won 99 seats in the parliamentary election and the Mutambara faction won 10, compared with 97 for ZANU–PF.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200804030001.html "Zanu-PF, MDC-T in photo finish"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002222742/http://allafrica.com/stories/200804030001.html |date=2 October 2012 }}, ''The Herald'' (allAfrica.com), 3 April 2008. On 28 April 2008, Mutambara and Tsvangirai announced that their factions were reuniting, thus enabling the MDC to have a clear parliamentary majority.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7371823.stm "Opposition reunites in Zimbabwe"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414214358/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7371823.stm |date=14 April 2009 }}, BBC News, 28 April 2008. On 1 June 2008, Mutambara was arrested at his home in Harare. According to his lawyer, the arrest was due to an article he wrote in ''The Standard'' in April, which allegedly included "falsehoods" and "contempt of court". In this article, he blamed Mugabe for the state of the economy and accused the security forces of committing abuses.Godfrey Marawanyika, [http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=3045&art_id=nw20080601170729234C285235 "Top Zim opposition figure arrested"] {{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, Sapa-AFP (''IOL''), 1 June 2008. On 3 June, Mutambara was released on a bail of 20 million [[Zimbabwean dollar]]s but he did not go to jail, with the next court date being set for 17 June. After the hearing on 3 June, he described his own suffering as minor compared to that of the people, saying that Mugabe's "human rights violations" would fail and vowing, "We will triumph over evil."[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=84&art_id=nw20080603132919207C311676 "Top Zim opposition figure freed"] {{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, AFP (''IOL''), 3 June 2008. ===SADC facilitated power-sharing agreement === On 15 September 2008, the leaders of the 14-member [[Southern African Development Community]] witnessed the signing of a power-sharing agreement between the two MDC factions and ZANU-PF. Under the deal, Mugabe remained president, Tsvangirai became prime minister,[http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/09/15/zimbabwe.powershare/?iref=mpstoryview edition.cnn.com, Rivals sign Zimbabwe power-share deal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232421/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/09/15/zimbabwe.powershare/?iref=mpstoryview |date=3 March 2016 }} the MDC controlled the police, ZANU-PF controlled the Army, and Mutambara became deputy prime minister.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article4756995.ece timesonline.co.uk, Power-sharing deal signed in Zimbabwe] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718194732/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article4756995.ece |date=18 July 2011}}[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26715920/ www.msnbc.msn, Zimbabwe power-sharing deal signed] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024163219/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26715920/|date=24 October 2012 }} ==References== {{Reflist|20em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Arthur Mutambara}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080701145808/http://www.bigthink.com/user/arthur-mutambara Interview with Arthur Mutambara] {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-new|party|reason=Party split between MDC and MDC-T}} {{s-ttl|title=Leader of the [[Movement for Democratic Change – Mutambara|Movement for Democratic Change-Mutambara]]|years=2005–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Zimbabwe government ministers 2009}} {{Zimbabwean political parties}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mutambara, Arthur}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Merton College, Oxford]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Management consultants]] [[Category:McKinsey & Company people]] [[Category:Movement for Democratic Change – Mutambara politicians]] [[Category:University of Zimbabwe alumni]] [[Category:Zimbabwean politicians]] [[Category:Zimbabwean Rhodes Scholars]] [[Category:Roboticists]]

{{User:RMCD bot/subject notice|1=Disney Streaming Services|2=Talk:BAMTech#Requested move 13 November 2018 }} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = BAMTech Media | logo = BAMTECH Media.png | logo_size = | trading_name = BAMTech Media | company_type = [[Subsidiary]] | founder = [[MLB Advanced Media]] | industry = {{Plainlist| * [[Streaming media]] * [[Video on demand]] }} | divisions = [[Disney+]]
[[ESPN+]] | revenue = | assets = | equity = | members = {{ubl|[[Walt Disney Direct-to-Consumer and International]] (75%)|[[MLB Advanced Media]] (15%)|[[National Hockey League]] (9%)|[[National Basketball Association]] (1%){{fact|date=August 2018}}}} | website = {{url|www.bamtechmedia.com}} | foundation = {{Start date and age|2015|2}} | location= [[Chelsea Market]] | location_city = [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = {{Plainlist| * Michael Paull (CEO){{cite news|last1=Spangler|first1=Todd|title=MLB, Disney Tap Amazon’s Michael Paull as CEO of BAMTech Streaming Venture|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/michael-paull-ceo-bamtech-mlbam-disney-1201992713/|accessdate=August 17, 2017|newspaper=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|date=February 21, 2017}} * Joe Inzerillo (Chief technology officer) * Eric Lieberman (Senior vice president) }} | subsid = BAMTech Europe (JV) (50%)
Cake Solutions | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 850 (2017) }} '''BAMTech Media''' is a technology subsidiary of [[The Walt Disney Company]] located in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].{{cite news |first1=Brooks |last1= BARNES |first2= John |last2=KOBLIN |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/08/business/media/bamtech-disney-streaming.html |title=Disney’s Big Bet on Streaming Relies on Little-Known Tech Company |work=The New York Times |date=2017-10-08 |accessdate=2018-03-09}} It was established in 2015 as a spin-off of [[MLB Advanced Media]]—the [[digital media]] arm of [[Major League Baseball]], focused on providing [[streaming video]] technology, particularly for [[over-the-top content]] (OTT) services. The company's major clients include [[ESPN]] (for its [[WatchESPN]] service), the NHL, [[HBO]] (for its [[HBO Now]] service), the [[PGA Tour]], [[Riot Games]] (for ''[[League of Legends]]'' [[e-sports]]), [[PlayStation Vue]], [[WWE Network]]{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2014/digital/news/hbo-cto-otto-berkes-resigns-as-network-enlists-mlb-to-build-ott-platform-1201375255/|title=HBO CTO Otto Berkes Resigns After Network Enlists MLB to Build OTT Platform|last=Spangler|first=Todd|date=December 9, 2014|work=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|access-date=August 9, 2017|language=en-US}} and [[TheBlaze]]. It was majority owned by MLB Advanced Media (which is, in turn, a consortium of MLB's [[List of Major League Baseball principal owners|principal team owners]]), with minority stakes held by the [[National Hockey League]] and other investors. Disney acquired a minority stake in the company in August 2016 for $1 billion, and the following year, announced its intent to increase its stake to a 75% controlling stake for $1.58 billion. The deal was approved by regulators in September 2017.{{Cite news|url= http://www.fiercecable.com/online-video/disney-gets-ok-from-ftc-for-1-58-billion-bamtech-buy|title=Disney gets OK from FTC for $1.58B BAMTech buy|last=Munson|first=Ben|date=September 20, 2017|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|accessdate= September 20, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url= http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/washington/feds-ok-disneys-bamtech-buy/168773|title=Feds OK Disney's BAMTech Buy|last=Eggerton|first=John|date=September 20, 2017|newspaper=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|accessdate= September 20, 2017|language=en-US}} Following the acquisition of BAMTech by Disney, the company began to develop two subscription streaming services aligned with Disney properties: the sports-oriented service [[ESPN+]], and the upcoming entertainment service [[Disney+]]. ==History== ===BAMTech Media=== BAMTech was founded in February 2015 through [[MLB Advanced Media]], spinning-out its streaming technology business into a separate company with outside investors. The formation of the company was approved by MLB Advanced Media's board of directors on August 13, 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/8/4/9090897/mlb-bam-live-streaming-internet-tv-nhl-hbo-now-espn|title=The Change Up: How baseball’s tech team built the future of television|author=Ben Popper|publisher=Vox Media|work=[[The Verge]]}} Under the plan, MLB-specific properties (such as MLB.com) would remain under league control.{{cite web|title=MLB considers spinning off its powerful streaming business|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/2/23/8092439/mlb-considers-mlbam-spinoff|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=August 4, 2015}} In August 2016, [[The Walt Disney Company]] acquired a 1/3 stake in the company for $1 billion, with an option to acquire a majority stake in the future.{{cite web|author=Ben Rains |url=https://www.sporttechie.com/disney-prepares-to-adapt-to-cord-cutters-with-new-mlbam-deal/ |title=Disney Prepares To Adapt To Cord Cutters With New MLBAM Deal |publisher=Sporttechie.com |date=2016-07-01 |accessdate=2018-03-09}} On November 1, 2016, BAMTech announced a partnership with [[Discovery Communications]] to form a European joint venture known as BAMTech Europe. Its first client is [[Eurosport]], the pan-European rightsholder of the [[Olympic Games]] beginning [[2018 Winter Olympics|2018]].{{cite web|title=Discovery, MLB's Streaming Business Partner to Launch BAMTech Europe|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/discovery-mlbs-streaming-business-partner-launch-bamtech-europe-942862|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|accessdate=November 1, 2016}} The following month, [[Riot Games]] announced a deal with BAMTech for the company to distribute and monetize broadcasts of [[League of Legends Championship Series|professional competitions]] in its multiplayer video game ''[[League of Legends]]'' through 2023. BAMTech will pay Riot at least $50 million per-year, and split advertising revenue.{{cite web|title=League of Legends’ maker inks rich broadcast contract, with an eye on premium content|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/12/18/13998614/league-of-legends-premium-tv-service-mlb|website=Polygon|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=December 18, 2016}}{{cite web|title=‘League of Legends’ E-Sports Contests Lure Newest Fan: Major League Baseball|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/league-of-legends-e-sports-contests-lure-newest-fan-major-league-baseball-1481889603|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=[[News Corp]]|accessdate=December 18, 2016}} On February 21, 2017, Michael Paull was named BAMTech's CEO.{{cite news|author=Todd Spangler |url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/michael-paull-ceo-bamtech-mlbam-disney-1201992713/ |title=MLB, Disney Tap Amazon’s Michael Paull as CEO of BAMTech Streaming Venture |work=Variety |date=2017-02-21 |accessdate=2018-03-09}} On August 8, 2017, Disney announced that it would increase its ownership in the company to a 75% controlling stake for $1.58 billion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/marvel-and-star-wars-films-will-ditch-netflix-for-disney/|title=Marvel and Star Wars films will ditch Netflix for Disney's own service|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en}} Disney also reiterated its plan to launch an [[ESPN+|ESPN-branded over-the-top service]] in early-2018 followed by a [[Disney+|Disney-branded direct-to-consumer streaming service]] in 2019. BAMTech Media was placed under [[Kevin A. Mayer]], Disney's senior executive vice president and chief strategy officer.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/disney-netflix-end-acquires-bamtech-espn-ott-services-1202519917/|title=Disney to End Netflix Deal, Sets Launch of ESPN and Disney-Branded Streaming Services|last=Spangler|first=Todd|date=August 8, 2017|work=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|access-date=August 9, 2017|language=en-US}} The company formally launched a website and corporate identity in September 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.multichannel.com/blog/bauminator/bamtech-gets-website-logo/415499|title=BAMTech Gets a Website, Logo|website=[[Multichannel News]]|publisher=[[NewBay Media]]|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06}} On November 7, 2017, BAMTech acquired the Manchester-based software firm Cake Solutions. As part of the corporate re-structuring, former director of Cake Solutions, Ian Brookes departed the company.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cakesolutions.net/teamblogs/cake-solutions-joins-bamtech-media|title=Cake Solutions Joins BAMTECH Media|last=Evison|first=Peter|publisher=Cake Solutions|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en}} In Disney's March 14, 2018 segment reorganization [[Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|in anticipation of integrating Fox assets]], BAMTech was transferred to [[Walt Disney Direct-to-Consumer and International]].{{cite news|last1=Spangler|first1=Todd|title=Disney Reorganizes Divisions, Creates Dedicated Direct-to-Consumer Streaming Unit|url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/disney-reorganizes-direct-to-consumer-streaming-unit-1202726528/|accessdate=March 15, 2018|work=Variety|date=March 14, 2018}} Bamtech named Kevin Swint as senior vice-president and general manager of the Disney forthcoming streaming service in January 2018 with Agnes Chu as programming executive.{{cite news|last1=Jarvey|first1=Natalie|title=BAMTech Taps Apple Veteran to Lead Disney OTT|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/bamtech-taps-apple-veteran-lead-disney-ott-1076109|accessdate=March 9, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=January 19, 2018|language=en}} ===Disney Streaming Services=== In October 2018, it was reported that the company had been internally renamed Disney Streaming Services.{{cite news |last1=Spangler |first1=Todd |title=Disney Appoints ESPN’s Aaron LaBerge as CTO of Streaming and International Division |url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/disney-aaron-laberge-cto-of-streaming-international-1202975587/ |accessdate=November 13, 2018 |work=Variety |date=October 10, 2018|quote=LaBerge and the DTCI Technology team will collaborate closely with Disney Streaming Services, the group previously known as BAMTech, which remains responsible for DTCI’s direct-to-consumer subscription streaming platforms.}} On October 31, 2018, [[ESPN International]] executive vice-president and managing director Russell Wolff was named executive vice-president and general manager of ESPN+.{{cite news |last1=Spangler |first1=Todd |title=Disney Puts Longtime ESPN Exec Russell Wolff in Charge of ESPN+ Streaming Service |url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/espn-russell-wolff-espn-plus-streaming-1203016265/ |accessdate=November 12, 2018 |work=Variety |date=October 31, 2018|quote=Wolff, as EVP and general manager of ESPN+, reports to Michael Paull, president of Disney Streaming Services (formerly referred to as BAMTech Media).}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|bamtechmedia.com}} {{Disney}} [[Category:Disney acquisitions]] [[Category:Disney Media Networks]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] [[Category:Corporate spin-offs]] [[Category:American companies established in 2015]] [[Category:American websites]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 2015]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2015]] [[Category:Media companies established in 2015]]

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Business plus.png|thumb|240px|The October 2004 issue of ''Business Plus'']] --> '''''Business Plus''''' is an [[Ireland|Irish]] [[business]] magazine published in [[Dublin]]<ref name=mstre/> by Nalac Limited. The magazine was established in 1998.<ref name=mstre>{{cite web|title=Business Plus Magazine|url=http://www.mediastreet.ie/en/businesses/business-plus-magazine|publisher=Media Street|accessdate=23 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723130252/http://www.mediastreet.ie/en/businesses/business-plus-magazine#|archive-date=2015-07-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> It is published monthly and its circulation was 10,660 (ABC) copies in 2006. Its editor is Nick Mulcahy, son of proprietor of ''[[The Phoenix (magazine)|The Phoenix]]'', John Mulcahy. It has {{ISSN|1393-5712}}.

Dr. '''Jan Constant Janssen''' (18 September 1895 in [[Belgium]], [[Vlimmeren]] – 15 April 1970 in [[Antwerp]]) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] physician and businessman. He was the third child (out of four) of Adriaan Victor Janssen (1854–1942) and Anna Catharina Eelen (1855–1929). He went to high school in [[Hoogstraten]] and studied medicine at the [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Catholic University of Leuven]] and the [[University of Ghent]]. On 16 April 1925, he married Margriet Fleerackers ([[Turnhout]], 5 January 1897-[[Vosselaar]], 23 September 1973), together they had four children. Their oldest son, [[Paul Janssen]], would become one of the most successful scientists in pharmaceutics.
==Career== He started his career as a family physician in [[Turnhout]], but in addition he was interested in business too. In 1921, he met Ladislas Richter in [[Vienna]], who was the son of Gedeon Richter, who owned a pharmaceutical factory in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]]. In 1933, he acquired the right to distribute the pharmaceutical products of [[Gedeon Richter Ltd.|Richter]], the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] pharmaceutical company, for Belgium, [[the Netherlands]] and [[Belgian Congo]]. On 23 October 1934, he founded the ''N.V. Produkten Richter'' in [[Turnhout]]. In 1937 Constant Janssen acquired an old factory building in the ''Statiestraat 78'' in [[Turnhout]] for his growing company, which he expanded during [[World War II]] into a four-storey building. In 1938 he closed his practice as a family physician and concentrated his effort of the expansion of his pharmaceutical business. His wife managed the production, quality control, and the administration of the company.
Still a medical student, his son Paul Janssen helped with the development of [[Perdolan]]. After [[World War II]], the brandname of the products was changed into ''Eupharma'', and later the company would evolve into [[Janssen Pharmaceutica]].
==Sources== * Dirk Collier (Ed.), ''Dr. Constant Janssen'', Janssen Pharmaceutica, 1996
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}

revision.text: [[File:Mean Euromoney Country Risk, March 2000 - March 2011.svg|thumb|346px|Mean Euromoney Country Risk, March 2000 - March 2011]] {{Financial risk types}} '''Country risk''' refers to the risk of investing or lending in a country, arising from possible changes in the business environment that may adversely affect operating profits or the value of assets in the country. For example, financial factors such as currency controls, devaluation or regulatory changes, or stability factors such as mass riots, civil war and other potential events contribute to companies' operational risks. This term is also sometimes referred to as [[political risk]]; however, country risk is a more general term that generally refers only to risks affecting all companies operating within or involved with a particular country. Political risk analysis providers and credit rating agencies use different methodologies to assess and rate countries' comparative [[Peren-Clement Index|risk exposure]]. Credit rating agencies tend to use quantitative econometric models and focus on financial analysis, whereas political risk providers tend to use qualitative methods, focusing on political analysis. However, there is no consensus on methodology in assessing credit and political risks. == Ratings == {| class="wikitable" |+ '''Country risk rankings Q4 2017''' |+ The least-risky countries for investment ! Rank !! Rank change !! Country !! Overall score |- ! 1 | '''-''' | [[Singapore]] || style="text-align:right;"|88.6 |- ! 2 | '''-''' | [[Norway]] || style="text-align:right;"|87.66 |- ! 3 | '''-''' | [[Switzerland]] || style="text-align:right;"|87.64 |- ! 4 | '''-''' | [[Denmark]] || style="text-align:right;"|85.67 |- ! 5 | ▲2 | [[Sweden]] || style="text-align:right;"|85.59 |- ! 6 | ▼1 | [[Luxembourg]] || style="text-align:right;"|83.85 |- ! 7 | ▼1 | [[Netherlands]] || style="text-align:right;"|83.76 |- ! 8 | ▲4 | [[Finland]] || style="text-align:right;"|83.1 |- ! 9 | '''-''' | [[Canada]] || style="text-align:right;"|82.98 |- ! 10 | ▲1 | [[Australia]] || style="text-align:right;"|82.18 |- | colspan="4" align="right"| Score out of 100. Rank change to previous quarter. Source: Euromoney Country Risk - published January 2018. [https://www.euromoney.com/research-and-awards/surveys-and-awards/country-risk-survey]: Survey which monitors the political and economic stability of 185 sovereign countries, according to ratings agencies and market experts. The information is compiled from Risk analysts; poll of economic projections; on GNI; World Bank’s Global Development Finance data; Moody’s Investors Service, Standard & Poor’s and Fitch IBCA; OECD consensus groups (source: ECGD); the US Exim Bank and Atradius UK; heads of debt syndicate and loan syndications; Atradius, London Forfaiting, Mezra Forfaiting and WestLB. |} The least-risky countries for investment. Ratings are further broken down into components including political risk, economic risk. Euromoney's quarterly country risk index [https://www.euromoney.com/research-and-awards/surveys-and-awards/country-risk-survey "Country risk survey"] monitors the political and economic stability of 185 sovereign countries. Results focus foremost on economics, specifically [[sovereign default]] risk and/or payment default risk for exporters (a.k.a. "trade credit" risk). [[File:Annual Trend in Euromoney Country Risk, March 2000 - March 2011.svg|thumb|283px|Annual Trend in Euromoney Country Risk, March 2000 - March 2011]] == Partial list of country risk premium == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090710013829/http://verlorenegeneration.de/landerisiken-im-uberblick/ List of Credit Default Swap premiums of various countries (German)] and [https://web.archive.org/web/20170112185716/https://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fverlorenegeneration.de%2Flanderisiken-im-uberblick%2F&sl=de&tl=en&history_state0= English Translation] == Partial list of credit risk rating agencies == * [http://www.fitchratings.com/ Fitch Ratings (U.S.)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070213081554/http://www.moodys.com/cust/default.asp Moody's (U.S.)] * [http://www.standardandpoors.com/ Standard & Poor's (U.S)] * [http://www.ctrisks.com/ CTRISKS (Greater China)] == Partial list of political risk analysis organizations == * [https://www.ihs.com/products/country-risk-analysis-forecasting.html/ IHS Country Risk] * [http://www.bmiresearch.com/ BMI Research] * [http://www.countryrisksolutions.com/ Country Risk Solutions] * [http://store.eiu.com/ Economist Intelligence Unit] * [http://www.eurasiagroup.net/ Eurasia Group] * [http://www.maplecroft.com/ Maplecroft] * [http://www.oxan.com/ Oxford Analytica] * [http://www.prsgroup.com The PRS Group, Inc.] == Downloadable country analysis and reports == * [https://www.thebenche.com/countryreports/ The Benche Analysis & Reports] * [http://www.eulerhermes.com/economic-research/country-reports/Pages/default.aspx Euler Hermes Country Reports] * [http://www.maplecroft.com/ Maplecroft] * [https://epub.prsgroup.com/free-samples The PRS Group, Inc.] == References == {{reflist}} {{Business-term-stub}} [[Category:Financial economics]] [[Category:Business terms]]

'''Cristian David''' (born '''Cristian Troacă'''; December 26, 1967) is a [[Romania]]n politician. A member of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL), he has been a member of the [[Senate of Romania|Romanian Senate]] for [[Vaslui County]] since 2004. In the [[Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu]] cabinet, he was Minister-Delegate for International Financing Programs and European Community Acquis from 2004 to 2007 and [[Ministry of Administration and Interior (Romania)|Minister of Interior and Administrative Reform]] from 2007 to 2008.
==Biography==
He was born in [[Bucharest]], and worked at a chemical equipment factory there from 1986 to 1991, rising to design engineer in 1990. Between 1992 and 2004, he held management positions at three different firms involved in import/export and consulting.<ref name="cvsenator"/> He paused his business activity from 1997 to 1998, when he was an adviser to the [[Ministry of Youth and Sport (Romania)|Youth and Sport Minister]], the future PNL President [[Crin Antonescu]].<ref name="cvsenator"/><ref name="vlasov">{{ro icon}} Mirela Corlăţan, Lucian Gheorghiu, [http://old.cotidianul.ro/guvernul_patriciu_fenechiu-24193.html "Guvernul Patriciu-Fenechiu" ("The Patriciu-Fenechiu Government")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827045809/http://old.cotidianul.ro/guvernul_patriciu_fenechiu-24193.html |date=2010-08-27 }}, ''Evenimentul Zilei'', 2 April 2007; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> In 1997 he graduated from the Faculty of Statistics, Cybernetics, and Computer Science of the [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies]], earning a doctorate in economics there in 2006. He was assistant professor in the Statistics and Economic Forecasting Department there from 2001 to 2004.<ref name="cvsenator">{{ro icon}} [https://www.senat.ro/FisaSenator.aspx?ParlamentarID=7cbd4c69-f2bb-4351-8567-418cc523bef0 Profile] at the Romanian Senate site; accessed August 25, 2010</ref>
Entering politics after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|fall]] of the [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]], he was coordinator of the University [[National Liberal Youth (Romania)|National Liberal Youth]] (TNL) from 1990 to 1993, rising to secretary general from 1993 to 1997. He belonged to the PNL's permanent central bureau in 1991-1993 and 2005-2006, and headed its foreign affairs department from 1997 to 2005. He was on the delegation of PNL national representatives in 2002-2004, and from 2003 to 2004 was on the electoral committee of the [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party]], in advance of the [[European Parliament election, 2004 (Romania)|2004 European Parliament election]].<ref name="cvsenator"/> During his first term in the Senate (2004-2008), he sat on the human rights, religious affairs and national minorities committee.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/parlam/structura.mp?idm=27&cam=1&leg=2004&pag=1&idl=1 2004-2008 parliamentary profile]; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> In his second term (2008-), he is on the joint committee providing oversight to the activities of ''[[Serviciul Român de Informaţii]]''.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/parlam/structura.mp?idm=39&cam=1&leg=2008&pag=1&idl=1 2008-2012 parliamentary profile]; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> Additionally, David held two positions in the Tăriceanu cabinet: Minister-Delegate for International Financing Programs and European Community Acquis from December 2004 to April 2007, when the post was disbanded, and Interior Minister from then until the cabinet left office in December 2008.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documentare.rompres.ro/guverne.php?i=12 Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu Government]; accessed August 25, 2010</ref>
David's first marriage took place in 2001, at which time he adopted his wife's surname, and ended in divorce.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/national-extern/cristian-david-lsd-cocaina-si-amfetamina~ni52sg "Cristian David, LSD, cocaină şi amfetamină" ("Cristian David, LSD, Cocaine and Amphetamines")], ''Ziarul de Iaşi'', 18 November 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref><ref name="revista2">{{ro icon}} [http://www.revista22.ro/abraham-ministrul-cristian-david-avea-droguri-in-casa-5019.html "Abraham: Ministrul Cristian David avea droguri în casă" ("Abraham: Minister Cristian David Had Drugs in His House")], ''22'', 18 November 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> His second marriage took place quietly in November 2005 in [[Vienna]], with a [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]] ceremony following six months later.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.observatordebacau.ro/2008/08/01/cancan-cristian-david-si-vanda-vlasov-divort-rapid.html "Cancan: Cristian David şi Vanda Vlasov, divorţ rapid" ("Cancan: Cristian David and Vanda Vlasov, Quick Divorce")], ''Observator de Bacău'', 1 August 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref><ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.9am.ro/stiri-revista-presei/Politica/33984/Ministrii-liberali-au-dansat-pe-rupte-la-cununia-colegului-Cristian-David.html "Miniştrii liberali au dansat pe rupte la cununia colegului Cristian David" ("Liberal Ministers Dance Lustily at Colleague Cristian David's Wedding")], ''Click'', 22 May 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> His second wife is Vanda Vlasov, daughter of the [[Iaşi]] lawyer [[Mihail Vlasov]]. Already an ally of the businessman and politician [[Relu Fenechiu]], David consolidated his relationship with Fenechiu through the marriage due to the latter's connections with Mihail Vlasov. Later, while Minister-Delegate, David was accused of taking no action when allegations surfaced that Vlasov embezzled [[Euro|€]]211,000 in [[European Union]] funds.<ref name="vlasov"/> Two scandals hit David near the end of his ministerial service. In October 2008, it emerged that the [[Romanian Police]], a part of his ministry, had signed contracts to purchase [[Dacia Logan]]s for some €70,000 each, with the opposition PD-L calling for his resignation and asserting that the police bought the cars for €12,000 under his PD-L predecessor.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://old.cotidianul.ro/pd_l_cere_demisia_lui_cristian_david_pentru_minciuna_si_fuga_de_raspundere-61130.html "PD-L cere demisia lui Cristian David pentru 'minciună şi fugă de răspundere'" ("PD-L Calls on Cristian David to Resign for 'Lies and Fleeing Responsibility'")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726051946/http://old.cotidianul.ro/pd_l_cere_demisia_lui_cristian_david_pentru_minciuna_si_fuga_de_raspundere-61130.html |date=2011-07-26 }}, ''Cotidianul'', 15 October 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> David refused to resign, instead firing police chief [[Gheorghe Popa]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Raluca Dan, [http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/david-ministrul-da-vina-si-fugi-824790.html "David, ministrul 'Dă vina şi fugi!'" ("David, Minister of 'Blame and Flee!'")], ''Evenimentul Zilei'', 17 October 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> The following month, [[Pavel Abraham]], a former chief of the Romanian Police, alleged that in 1995, police officers searching David's home discovered [[Lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]], [[amphetamine]] and [[cocaine]]. In reply, David stated that the residence was his girlfriend's and was being rented to his [[Netherlands|Dutch]] business partner, and that he was questioned as a witness in the case.<ref name="revista2"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}} {{RomanianInteriorMinisters}} {{First Tăriceanu Cabinet}} {{Second Tăriceanu Cabinet}}

'''Brandeis Denham Jolly''' (born August 25, 1935)<ref name=otf>[http://www.livewithculture.ca/film/screen-time-for-caribbean-tales/ "Business: Real Life Narratives - Brandeis Denham Jolly"]. ''Literacy for Black History'', Ontario Teachers' Federation.</ref> is a Jamaican Canadian businessman, publisher, broadcaster and civil rights activist and author of ''In the Black: My Life.'' For many years he was the president of [[Milestone Radio|Milestone Communications]].<ref>[http://www.dailyxtra.com/toronto/radio-ga-ga-56914 "Radio ga ga"]. ''Daily Xtra'', December 15, 1999.</ref>
==Early life and education==
Jolly was born in Negril, [[Jamaica]], where he attended [[Cornwall College, Jamaica|Cornwall College]].<ref>[http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/westernnews/25748_High-honours-for-Cornwall-College-stalwarts "Western News: High honours for Cornwall College stalwarts"]. ''Jamiaca Observer'', May 18, 2002</ref> He studied at [[McGill University]], graduating in 1955 with a degree in science.<ref name=gleaner>[http://old.jamaica-gleaner.com/extra/article.php?id=1492 "Denham Jolly honoured"]. ''Jamaica Gleaner'', Eddie Grant, March 8, 2012</ref>
==Career== Jolly returned to Jamaica after graduation and conducted research about nutrition for the government of Jamaica.<ref name="Holas2000">{{cite book|author=Wilma Patricia Holas|title=Millennium Minds : 100 Black Canadians|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qc4RAQAAIAAJ|year=2000|publisher=Pan-African Publications|isbn=978-0-9682734-4-9|page=119}}</ref> He later moved to Canada and gathered information about air pollution for [[Metropolitan Toronto]].<ref name=otf /> After studying and obtaining a teaching certificate, Jolly taught science at [[Forest Hill Collegiate Institute|Forest Hill Collegiate]] in Toronto.<ref name=otf /><ref name="Williams2006">{{cite book|author=Dawn P. Williams|title=Who's who in Black Canada 2: Black Success and Black Excellence in Canada : a Contemporary Directory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_UtdQ6NsvYkC&pg=PA200|year=2006|publisher=Who's Who in Black Canada|isbn=978-0-9731384-2-9|pages=200–}}</ref>
Jolly started into business by buying a rooming house, in which he lived. He went on to purchase a Day’s Inn hotel, nursing homes in Texas and Mississauga, and two medical laboratories.<ref name=otf />
In 1982 Jolly bought and published of the newspaper ''Contrast''.<ref name=gleaner /><ref>[http://rrj.ca/the-audible-minorities/ "The Audible Minorities"]. ''Ryerson Review of Journalism'', Martin Cash — April 1, 1984</ref><ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/Research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=108537462&privcapId=108503114&previousCapId=108503114&previousTitle=Milestone%20Radio%20Inc. "Denham Jolly". ] Profile at Bloomberg.</ref> That year he also founded and led the Black Business and Professional Association.<ref name=otf /> He was also active in the civil rights organizations and spoke out on social justice issues as a member of the [[Black Action Defence Committee]].<ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/posted-toronto/remembering-black-rights-activist-dudley-laws "Remembering: Black-rights activist Dudley Laws"]. ''National Post'', Peter Kuitenbrouwer | March 24, 2011</ref>
Jolly launched Canada's first Black-owned radio station FLOW 93.5 [[CFXJ-FM]] through his company [[Milestone Radio|Milestone Communications]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1021711/canada-to-get-first-black-owned-urban-format-radio-station/|title=Canada To Get First Black-Owned, Urban-Format Radio Station|author=Will Comerford|date=2000-06-22|publisher=MTV News}}</ref><ref name="TatorHenry1998">{{cite book|author1=Carol Tator|author2=Frances Henry|author3=Winston Mattis|title=Challenging Racism in the Arts: Case Studies of Controversy and Conflict|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ogu8W_iiscsC&pg=PA131|year=1998|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-7170-5|pages=131–}}</ref> The fight to get the license took a dozen years<ref>[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/rhythm-and-blues-emc/ "Rhythm and Blues"]. ''The Canadian Encyclopedia'', January 31, 2014.</ref> and his struggle was featured in the Washington Post as an example of racial barriers in Canada.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Howard Schneider|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/canada/stories/mosaic122997.htm|title=WashingtonPost.com: Canada Special Report: For Some, the Racial `Mosaic' Pales at Top|work=Washington Post|date=December 29, 1997}}</ref> and the Toronto Star.<ref>Toronto Star, January 30, 2000. p.D7</ref> The license was finally awarded in June 2000.<ref name="Canada2000">{{cite book|author=Canada|title=The Canada Gazette: Part II.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SFlKAQAAIAAJ|year=2000|publisher=Queen's Printer|page=xliv}}</ref> It was supported by both the Toronto Star<ref>Black Community gets its radio voice, Toronto Star, June 29, 2000, p.A27</ref> and the Toronto Sun, which ran an editorial saying that "At long last the dinosaurs at the [[Canadian Radio and Telecommunications Commission]] have admitted Toronto needs a black-owned urban format station on the FM dial."<ref>A Radio Milestone, Toronto Sun editorial, June 19, 2000</ref>
FLOW 93.5 went on air in February 2001. The station Black-owned, and played and actively promoted Canada’s Black musicians, including [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and Shad. It aired as a mixture of talk and music, including O.T.A. (On the Air) Live!, a weekly interview program with hip hop artists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_ca/article/ota-live-ty-harper-rez-digital-flow-935-interview|title=Exploring the History of 'O.T.A. Live': Toronto's Most Beloved Radio Show - Noisey|website=noisey|language=en-us|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref> FLOW 93.5 devoted airtime to black-oriented music and provided opportunities for many black Canadians in the radio industry.
In 2005 FLOW won the Station of the Year Award in the Contemporary Hit Radio category at the Canadian Music Week Industry Awards.<ref>[http://www.broadcastermagazine.com/broadcasting/flow-93-5-takes-home-chr-station-of-the-year-award/1000038393/ "Flow 93.5 takes home CHR station of the year award "]. ''Broadcaster Magazine'', March 8, 2005</ref> That year Jolly invested in a radio station in Edmonton, called ''The Bounce''.<ref name=otf />
Jolly was on the boards of the YMCA and the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] and he has won awards for his cultural contributions including the Black Media Pioneer Award.<ref>[http://www.livewithculture.ca/film/from-nuclear-physics-to-filmmaking/ "From Nuclear Physics to Filmmaking]. ''To Live with Culture'', July 2, 2012. Christopher Jones</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://caribbeantales-newz.blogspot.ca/2012/01/media-pioneer-to-be-honored-in-black.html|title=Media Pioneer to be honored in Black History Month|website=caribbeantales-newz.blogspot.ca|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref> the African Canadian Lifetime Achievement Award<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://africancanadianachievementawards.com/2011-awardees/|title=African Canadian Achievement Awards {{!}} 2011 Awardees|website=africancanadianachievementawards.com|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref> and the Canadian Urban Institute's City Soul Award in 2006. In 2007 he was presented with a Black History Award from the Markham African Caribbean Association.<ref>[http://www.guidingstar.ca/Black_History_Month_Celebrated.htm "Black History Month Celebrated with Impressive Ceremony at Markham Town Centre"]. ''Guiding Star'', Feb 27, 2007.</ref>
In 2008 Jolly donated $50,000 towards the endowment of the Jean Augustine Chair in Education in the New Urban Environment at York University.<ref>[http://yfile.news.yorku.ca/2008/07/22/york-to-the-power-of-50-launch-of-the-jean-augustine-chair/ "York to the Power of 50: Launch of the Jean Augustine Chair"]. York University website. 22.07.2008</ref>
Jolly sold his radio holdings in 2011 for $27 millon.<ref>[http://www.excal.on.ca/off-air-torontos-black-community-loses-radio-voice/ "Off air: Toronto’s Black community loses radio voice"]. ''Excalibur Magazine'', Feb 14, 2012. Tricia Kanhai</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2011/02/02/ctv_takes_over_flow_935_fm.html|title=CTV takes over Flow 93.5 FM {{!}} Toronto Star|website=thestar.com|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mississauga.com/whatson-story/3161864-radio-pioneer-sells-station/ " Radio pioneer sells station"]. ''Mississauga News'', Feb 03, 2011</ref> He then invested US$750,000 in a real estate development project in Barbados.<ref>[http://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/24961/jolly "Not jolly"]. ''Nation News'', MARIA BRADSHAW, 28 July 2013</ref>
His memoir, ''In the Black: My Life'' was published in February 2017 by [[ECW Press]].<ref>[http://www.quillandquire.com/omni/daily-deals-bundoran-press-acquires-two-new-novels/ "Daily Deals: Bundoran Press acquires two novels; Kate Blair’s Transferral optioned for TV; ECW acquires memoir by Denham Jolly"]. ''[[Quill and Quire]]'', by Becky Robertson. May 1, 2016.</ref> The book won the 2017 [[Toronto Book Award]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/books/b-denham-jolly-s-memoir-about-growing-up-black-in-toronto-wins-toronto-book-award-1.4353253 "B. Denham Jolly's memoir about growing up Black in Toronto wins Toronto Book Award"]. [[CBC Books]], October 13, 2017.</ref>
== Honours ==
The City of Toronto, on February 28, 2017, the final day of Black History Month, announced the naming of a street in a new Scarborough sub-division in honour of Mr. Denham Jolly, a Black pioneer in Canada’s radio broadcasting industry. "Jolly Way" will commemorate the exceptional contributions to Canada of Denham Jolly. Jolly Way is located near the southwest corner of Midland Avenue and Ellesmere Avenue, in a residential neighbourhood under development by the Goldman Group. "It is most appropriate that approval to name a street after Mr. Jolly has come through today, the last day of Black History Month 2017," said Councillor Michael Thompson, Chair of Toronto’s Economic Development Committee. "Mr. Jolly has been instrumental in giving voice to the culture, achievements, challenges and aspirations of Toronto’s Black and Caribbean communities when few channels for such messages were available," Thompson added.
<ref>http://pridenews.ca/2017/02/28/north-toronto-street-name-honour-african-canadian-radio-pioneer-b-denham-jolly/</ref>
==Further reading== *B. Denham Jolly. ''In the Black: My Life''. ECW Press, 2017. {{ISBN|1770413782}}
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
{{authority control}}
